questions.Q: A simple pendulum of length $$L$$ is pivoted at the roof of an elevator that moves upward with constant acceleration $$a$$ If the pendulum executes oscillations, the time period for the small oscillations of the pendulum is:
questions.E: When the pendulum is in equillibrium for an observer located in the elevator, the effective acceleration of gravity for the pendulum bob is $$a_N=g+a\text{.}$$ Thus, for small oscillations, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{L}{a_N}}=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{L}{g+a}}$$

questions.Q: A simple pendulum of length $$L$$ is pivoted at the roof of an elevator that moves downward with constant acceleration $$a$$ If the pendulum executes  oscillations, the time period for the small oscillations of the pendulum is:
questions.E: When the pendulum is in equillibrium for an observer located in the elevator, the effective acceleration of gravity for the pendulum bob is $$a_N=g-a\text{.}$$ Thus, for small oscillations, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{L}{a_N}}=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{L}{g+a}}$$

questions.Q: A simple pendulum of length $$L$$ is pivoted at the roof of a container that moves rightwward with constant acceleration $$a$$ If the pendulum executes  oscillations, the time period for the small oscillations of the pendulum is:
questions.E: For an observer located in the container, the effective acceleration of gravity for the pendulum bob is $$a_N=\sqrt{a^2+g^2}\text{.}$$ When the pendulum is in equillibrium the string is parallel $$\vec{a}_N$$ and in the oscillating state the oscillations occurs about the equillibrium position. Thus, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{L}{a_N}}=2\pi\frac{L}{\sqrt{a^2+g^2}}$$

questions.Q: A simple pendulum of length $$L$$ is pivoted at the roof of a container that moves down along an inclined plane with constant acceleration $$a$$. The inclined plane makes an angle $$\beta$$ with the horizontal line. If the pendulum executes  oscillations, the time period for the small oscillations of the pendulum is:
questions.E: For an observer located in the container, the effective acceleration of gravity for the pendulum bob is $$a_N=\sqrt{a^2+g^2-2ag\sin\beta}\text{.}$$ When the pendulum is in equillibrium the string is parallel $$\vec{a}_N$$ and in the oscillating state the oscillations occurs about the equillibrium position. Thus, $$\\T=2\pi\sqrt{\frac{L}{a_N}}=2\pi\frac{L}{\sqrt{a^2+g^2-2ag\sin\beta}}$$

questions.Q: Two identical point-like electrically charged particles are fixed and $$2L$$ apart. The charge of the particles is $$Q$$. Between the particles and in the same line connecting them a tiny ball of charge $$q$$ and mass $$m$$ is located. If the ball is displaced a distance $$x$$ from its equilibrium position and released, the period for the small oscillations of the ball is :
questions.E: The net electric force on the charge $$q$$ is $$\\ F=F_1-F_2=\frac{kQq}{(L+x)^2}-\frac{kQq}{(L-x)^2}\\=kQq\Big[\frac{1}{(L+x)^2}-\frac{1}{(L-x)^2}\Big]\\=\frac{kQq}{L^2}\Big[\frac{1}{(1+\frac{x}{L})^2}-\frac{1}{(1-\frac{x}{L})^2}\Big]\\=\frac{kQq}{L^2}\Big[(1+\frac{x}{L})^{-2}-(1-\frac{x}{L})^{-2} \Big]\\ \approx  \frac{kQq}{L^2}\Big[ (1-\frac{2x}{L})-(1+\frac{2x}{L})\Big]\\=-\frac{4kQq}{L^3}x\\$$ We have used the approximation $$(1+X)^n \approx 1+nX$$ which is valid for $$X<<1$$, being $$n$$ a real number; in this case $$X=\frac{x}{L}$$ and $$n=-2\text{.}\\$$ Applying Newton's second law to the ball: $$\\ F=ma\therefore\,a=-\frac{4kQq}{mL^3}x\\$$ This is the equation of a simple harmonic motion. Thus, $$T=\frac{2\pi}{\omega}$$ where $$\omega ^2=\frac{4kQq}{mL^3}$$ and therefore $$\\ T=\pi L\sqrt{\frac{mL}{kQq}}$$

questions.Q: A thin ring of radius $$R$$ has an electric charge $$Q$$ iniformly distributed. A tiny small particle of charge $$-q$$ and mass $$m$$ is located along the axis of the ring a distance $$x$$ from its center. If $$x$$ is small and the ball is free to move, the period of the small oscillations of the ball is:
questions.E: Let us find the net electric force on the charge $$q$$. To do this, we take a differential of charge $$dQ$$ from the ring and calculate the force on $$q$$. By symmetry, the net force is along the x-axis. Thus, $$\\ dF_x=-\frac{kdQq}{r^2}\cos\beta=-\frac{kqdQ}{r^2}\frac{x}{r}=-kqdQ\frac{x}{(x^2+R^2)^{3/2}}\\$$ Using the priciple of superposition $$\\ F_x=\int dF_x=-kq\frac{x}{(x^2+R^2)^{3/2}}\int_0^QdQ=-kqQ\frac{x}{(x^2+R^2)^{3/2}}\\$$ For small $$x$$ the previous equation can be rewritten as $$\\F_x=-kQq\frac{x}{\Big[ R^2(1+\frac{x^2}{x^2})^{\frac{3}{2}}\Big]}=\\ -\frac{kQqx}{R^3}\Big[1+\frac{x^2}{R^2}\Big]^{-\frac{3}{2}}\\ =-\frac{kQqx}{R^3}\Big[1-\frac{3}{2}\frac{x^2}{R^2}\Big] \approx -\frac{kQq}{R^3}x\\$$ We have used the approximation $$(1+X)^n \approx 1+nX$$ which is valid for $$X<<1$$, being $$n$$ a real number; in this case $$X=\frac{x^2}{R^2}$$ and $$n=-\frac{3}{2}\\$$ Applying Newton's second law to the ball: $$\\ F=ma\therefore\,a=-\frac{kQq}{mR^3}x\\$$ This is the equation of a simple harmonic motion. Thus, $$T=\frac{2\pi}{\omega}$$ where $$\omega ^2=\frac{kQq}{mR^3}$$ and therefore $$\\ T=2\pi R\sqrt{\frac{Rm}{kQq}}$$

questions.Q: A body of mass $$m$$ is connected to two springs of elastic constants $$k_1$$ and $$k_2$$. The other ends of the springs are fixed. Initially, the springs are unstretched, afterwards the mass is displaced a distance $$x$$ away from its equillibrium position and released. If friction is neglected, the period of the small oscillations of the body is:
questions.E: The figure shows the two horizontal forces on the body $$F_1=-k_1x$$ and $$F_2=-k_2x$$$ when it is located at the right of the equillibrium position (point o)\\$$ Applying the Newton's second law to the body we have $$\\-k_1x-kx_2=ma\\ \therefore a=-\frac{k_1+k_2}{m}x\\$$ This is the equation of a simple harmonic motion. Thus, $$T=\frac{2\pi}{\omega}$$ where $$\omega ^2=\frac{k_1+k_2}{m}$$ and therefore $$\\ T=2\pi \sqrt{\frac{m}{k_1+k_2}}$$
